text:
HAZEL SIVE: At
this point, you've

tried your class exercise
on allele segregation.

You should be able
to follow alleles
segregating during meiosis.

And you should be able
to do this for two
chromosomes and two alleles.

Let's move on now to the next
topic, which you will see

is highly related to
allele segregation.

And that is the topic
of genetics and crosses.

We've talked a lot about
genes and gene variants

that are caused by
changes in DNA sequence.

And that, indeed, is how
inheritance works and changes.

It's all about what the gene
looks like at the DNA sequence
level.

But sometimes, we
really don't understand

what the DNA sequences
are that are giving rise
to a particular trait.

And then we need a
different set of tools

to help us understand something
about how traits are inherited,

and how a particular
trait might be regulated.

And this is important
across the board.

It's very important
when it comes

to things like diseases, where
we try to understand what

it is that is
causing the disease,

even if we don't know what
the gene or genes are,

and even if we really think that
there might be something very
complicated going on.

So genetics is the set of
tools to help us understand
inheritance and gene function--

genetics tools to understand
genes and inheritance.

These tools are what we
need to discuss so that you

can use the power of genetics
to understand something
about a particular question.

And we need some definitions
before we can move on.

Let's make a listing, a
short listing of some key

points you need to
know the terms for.

"Genotype" refers to the
genes of an individual.

"Phenotype," we've mentioned,
is an observable trait

that you can see by eye or
by some kind of other assay.

"Gene"-- in
molecular biology, we

talked about the DNA
sequence required
to make the final product.

In genetics, the definition
is slightly different.
It's a little vaguer.

It's referred to as
the "hereditary unit."

"Allele"-- for completeness'
sake we'll write it again--
are alternate gene forms.

And then the last one
we need is "generation."

And this refers to
individuals that

are born at the same time
from the same parents.

We can talk about
the P generation,
which are the parents.

We can talk about the
F1 generation, which are
the first generation offspring.

We can talk about the F2,
which are the second generation

offspring, et cetera.,
abbreviating "generation" there
with "gen."

Those are some of the key
terms that we need as we go

and we consider some of these
observable characteristics.

Well, let's think about some of
the observable characteristics

and some of the genetics that
we are going to talk about
by looking at this slide.

Genetic traits can have
the following terminology--
they can be dominant.

They can be recessive,
co-dominant,
or incompletely dominant.

And we'll talk about some
of those in a moment.

But for example, you may have
freckles or not freckles.
Freckles is considered dominant.

And if someone were
to mate with someone

who didn't have freckles,
probably the offspring
would be freckled.

You might know about
rolling your tongue.

Some people can
roll their tongue.
I can roll my tongue, can you?

Rolling your tongue is
considered dominant.

It's something that if two
people get together and have

offspring, then the
children, or some of them,

will be able to
roll their tongues.

In flowers, moving
away from humans,

there are flowers
that are mixed colors.

There is a dahlia
that's red and white.

That's an example of a trait
that is called "incompletely

dominant" or
"co-dominant," sometimes.

And that, again,
will give you a sense

of how genetic traits can move
around in different organisms.

And this bottom example
is very interesting.

This is a sickle
cell, a red blood cell

that, with a particular gene
variant, a particular allele,

can change from a round
cell or a disk-shaped cell

to a kind of a
plate-shaped, indented cell.

And this has to do with
a characteristic called
"recessive."

And it's associated
with various disorders,

but can also be very useful
in certain circumstances.

So this gives you
some sense of where

we're going to go in
this part of the lecture.

And you may not have ever
heard of these terms,

and that's fine,
because you will now.

I've also given you
a listing of some

of these genetic
terms that you can

refer to in addition to
what is on the board.

Let us now consider
genetic crosses.

And we're going to start off
with genetic crosses that
follow a genotype.

And particularly,
we are going to talk

about monohybrid
crosses, which means

that there is one single trait
involved and likely one gene.

"Monohybrid cross"-- that means
one trait, probably one gene.

And we can write down
this genetic cross
in the following way--
we'll write the parents.
We'll write the genome type.

We'll write what gametes
they are going to form.

And then we'll write what the
first generation offspring
are going to look like.

So we're going to do
a theoretical breeding
experiment here.

The parents are
designated P1 and P2.

And let us say that the
genotype of the first parent
is big B, big B.

This means that that parent has
the alleles of the Apple gene

that we previously talked about,
the big B version and the big B

version, on that
particular chromosome.

We're ignoring all
the other chromosomes,
just looking at the B.
So that's the allele.
And it's diploid.
So it's got two of the alleles--
allele and it's diploid.

P2 let's designate as
having two little b's.
It's also diploid.

So it's got two of them
and that's the alleles
that it has of the Apple gene.

Now let's think about
meiosis and the products
of meiosis in Parent 1.

In this case, it's
pretty simple.

You're big B, big
B and so there's

only one type of outcome,
one type of gamete you're
going to make after meiosis.

And it is going to have the
haploid genotype of big B.

So that is the haploid genotype,
because gametes are always
haploid.

And for P2, the gamete
is going to be little b,
because that's the only option.
There's only little b's.

And it's only going
to be one of them,
because again, it's haploid.

So we are now going to cross
these parents to one another.

When mating occurs,
there is one male gametes

and one female gamete
that come together
to make a diploid organism.

They restore the diploid
number of chromosomes.

And so these two gametes
will come together.

And in the first
generation offspring,

there will be one big
B and one little b.

This offspring is
diploid, again,

and 100% of those offspring
will be big B, little
b in their genotype.

This is really
important in genetics.

And this is one way you can
represent this type of thing,

but there's actually
a better way.

And I'm going to show
it to you on a slide.

And the better way is
called a "Punnett square."
I'm going to make a note here--
Punnett square representation.

I have lots of practice of
working with Punnett squares,

but I needed to do
this in longhand

before you could look
at a Punnett square.

So let us look at
this Punnett square.

And actually, I want
to make one other point

before we look at the Punnett
square representation.

If you have two of
the same alleles--

big B, big B or
little b, little b--

you get a special term, and
that is called "homozygous."

If you have one big B
and one little b, two

different alleles, you
are called "heterozygous."

So these big B, big B and little
b, little b are homozygous.

And the big B, little b,
of which 100% of the cross

results in, those would
be called "heterozygous."

And those are terms
you should know.
So let's look at our slides.

And here in the
Punnett square, you

can see that there's a
kind of formalization
of how you represent things.

The parents are
represented along the sides
and the top of the square.

And the gametes are
represented next to the parent.

So you kind of start with
the parental genotype.

And then you split
it into the gametes

that can form along the
top and along the side.
And then you do the cross.

You say that gamete big B will
match up with gamete little b,
and give you big B, little b.

Gamete big B will match
up with this little b

to give you big B,
little b, and so on.

And you do this for every
combination of gametes

from each parent,
filling in the squares

with the outcome
of the combination.
It's logical and it's organized.

And it's very helpful
in figuring out

the genotype and the proportions
of the different genotypes.
This is a simple example.

And every one-- this is
the same example that I did
on the board--

all of the offspring
are big B, little b.

But this is a different
Punnett square representation

of genetic crosses
using genotype.

Genetic crosses can
also follow traits,

so that you can match up
the genotype with the trait,

or indeed, just follow
the trait and later on try
to figure out the genotype.

For example-- let's have another
example to extend our example--

let us have our parents
and our genotype.

And now we're going
to add phenotype,
another word for "trait."

And then we're going to
have our first generation.

So our parents,
again, are P1 and P2.
And they're going to cross.
They're going to mate.
Here is P1.

We'll give it the same
genotype as before,

but the difference is we're
now going to add a phenotype.

Big B, big B has
a green phenotype.
The apples are green.

Little b, little b has
a yellow phenotype.
The apples are yellow.

When you cross those together,
as before, you get out the F1.
The F1 is big B, little b.
And they are all green.

Aha-- so you started with
green and yellow apple plants,
apple trees.

And when you cross them,
you came out with all green.

In this example, green
is said to be dominant.

And this would refer
to the B allele.

Yellow is said to be
recessive relative to big B.

That would be the
little b allele.

So here are two terms,
green and yellow,
defining dominant and recessive.

Which of the traits carries
on into the next generation?

What does this look like
on a Punnett square?

We can do the same
example exactly,
but now we can add phenotypes.

And I'm going to do
something a little tricky

here, because in the
example that I've given you,

I've shown you
actually an F1 cross.

So let us keep that
slide in our minds,

but let's go back to the
board just for a moment

before you can really interpret
the slide that I've put up.

So we've followed the
cross with various traits.

But then, what I've done to make
it interesting and to show you

some other principles is
that I've done an F1 cross.

In an F1 cross, you're
taking the offspring

from that initial parental
cross and you are crossing them
to one another.

So here, the parents,
genotype, and the phenotype--

the parents would be the
F1 crossed by the F1.

And from our previous
board, those F1 plants

have the genotype big B,
little b, both of them.

And the phenotype
they have is green.

And now, we can look and
see how this cross reads out

using a Punnett square,
looking at a Punnett square.

So let's now look
at our slide where
I've got this cross indicated.

The parents are F1 with green
phenotypes and the genotype
is big B, little b.

And you can see now that
the gametes from each parent
can be one of two kinds.

They can be big B or
they can be little b.

Parent 1 can give big B
and little b, Parent 2
big B, little b.

And when you fill in
your Punnett square,

you can see that
there are actually
three different genotypes.

There is big B, big
B, big B, little b,

and little b little
b, three genotypes.
There are only two phenotypes.

There is green or
there is yellow.
Two points from this--

firstly, you can see that
genotype does not always
go with phenotype.

The big B, big B and
the big B, little b

have the same phenotype, but
they've got different genotype.

And the little b, little b
has a different phenotype

to the genotypes that
have got a big B.

And this, again, is
an example of how

we know that the big
B allele is dominant
to the little b allele.

You only get yellow apples
when you've got two little b's.

When you've got any one big
B, you're a green apple.

So this is a Punnett
square representation

that has both genotype
and phenotype.

And then the last thing
I want to tell you,

which I'll put on
the same board here,

is something called
a "test cross."

You may not know what the
genotype of the parents are.

You might want to
figure this out.

You might think, are the
parents big B, big B,
or big B, little b?

You can figure this
out if you cross

those parents to something
that is a true breeding strain.

And a true breeding
strain in this case

will be a homozygous
recessive strain.

So you're going to cross
this to little b, little
b, which is homozygous.

It's got two of
the same alleles.
And it is recessive.

And it is called
"true breeding,"

where "true breeding" means that
if you cross little b, little

b to itself, you'll come up
with yellow all the time.

You'll never suddenly
start getting green.

True breeding means
you know what you
have in your breeding stock.

So this notion of
a test cross is

something you can use
to figure out genotype.

And here is a slide that
has got a test cross

where you're not
sure if it's big
B, big B or big B, little b.

You make two separate or you
make a number of crosses.
And I've shown you two outcomes.

If Parent 1 was big B, big
B, all of your offspring
would be green.

If Parent 1 was big B, little
b, half of your offspring

would be green and half
of them would be yellow.

And you can follow that
on the Punnett square
with the genotypes associated.

So we've talked now a bunch
about monohybrid cross.

And you can go and look
at the class exercise

and practice some Punnett
squares on the class exercise

to cement these
kinds of concepts.
